channel.title: davewiner tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from davewiner.

item.title: Was 2-factor such a good idea?
item.description:
Now that all our services use our phones to allow us to connect to our accounts, what happens if you lose your phone? I don't mean just the physical phone, what if you lose control of the number? It can happen.
I'm thinking of switching carriers, but do I dare? What if the number gets lost in the transition. All of a sudden I can't get to anything.
item.source:markdown:
Now that all our services use our phones to allow us to connect to our accounts, what happens if you lose your phone? I don't mean just the physical phone, what if you lose control of the number? It can happen.
I'm thinking of switching carriers, but do I dare? What if the number gets lost in the transition. All of a sudden I can't get to anything.

item.title: Two-way RSS
item.description:
I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year, specifically RSS going in both directions. Apps that can read RSS and also write RSS.
As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like [Substack](https://t.co/MCOiYl6ihr) only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.
But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.
Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.
Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious. I've asked writers who use Substack how they feel about this, with mixed results. None of the writers are thinking about it very much, apparently.
item.source:markdown:
I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year, specifically RSS going in both directions. Apps that can read RSS and also write RSS.
As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like [Substack](https://t.co/MCOiYl6ihr) only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.
But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.
Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.
Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious.
I've asked writers who use Substack how they feel about this, with mixed results. None of the writers are thinking about it very much, apparently.

item.description: Putin said something in the lead-up to the war in Ukraine. I'm paraphrasing. He said he can buy any western politician he wants. If true, that explains a lot of what we see happening in US politics.
item.source:markdown:
Putin said something in the lead-up to the war in Ukraine. I'm paraphrasing.
He said he can buy any western politician he wants.
If true, that explains a lot of what we see happening in US politics.

item.description: Dear twitter, I'm working on a new product, and twitter is rejecting links to the site because it thinks it's a malware site. It's a brand new domain, didn't exist two weeks ago. There's no malware. What can be done to fix this??
item.source:markdown: Dear twitter, I'm working on a new product, and twitter is rejecting links to the site because it thinks it's a malware site. It's a brand new domain, didn't exist two weeks ago. There's no malware. What can be done to fix this??

item.title: Twitter + RSS
item.description:
My Twitter feed has an RSS feed now. So, with any luck, what I’m writing here will appear in my feed reader soon. That’s all I wanted to say for now. :smile:
It worked. ;-) https://t.co/MeYtpdL3VN
item.source:markdown:
My Twitter feed has an RSS feed now.
So, with any luck, what I’m writing here will appear in my feed reader soon.
That’s all I wanted to say for now. :smile:
It worked. ;-) https://t.co/MeYtpdL3VN

item.description: @conoro @SlackAPI i know. and there were so many people angry with me, or people who wanted to take over, that after 2.0 i just moved on. but then i realized why can't i continue to work on the project. what a weird world. so i think this is the year for RSS to become something more than it is.
item.source:markdown: @conoro @SlackAPI i know. and there were so many people angry with me, or people who wanted to take over, that after 2.0 i just moved on. but then i realized why can't i continue to work on the project. what a weird world. so i think this is the year for RSS to become something more than it is.

item.description: Guy Kawasaki managed developer relations at Apple when I was a Mac developer, when the Mac was struggling to get going, and in its first boom. And he gave us the killer idea that put our product over the top. :-) https://t.co/aEjJNUUz19
item.source:markdown:
Guy Kawasaki managed developer relations at Apple when I was a Mac developer, when the Mac was struggling to get going, and in its first boom.
And he gave us the killer idea that put our product over the top. :-) https://t.co/aEjJNUUz19
